authors: Andrew R Abela; Caleb J Browne; Derya Sargin; Thomas D Prevot; Xiao Dong; Zhaoxia Li; Evelyn K Lambe; Paul J Fletcher; H I G H L I G H T S
title: Median raphe serotonin neurons promote anxiety-like behavior via inputs to the dorsal hippocampus
abstract: Optogenetic stimulation of serotonin neurons in median raphe nucleus (MRN) increases anxiety-like behaviour in female mice. • This stimulation is associated with increased serotonin release in the dorsal hippocampus (dHC). • Optogenetic stimulation of serotonin fibers in the dHC increases the expression of anxiety-like behaviour in female mice. • Stimulation of serotonin neurons in the MRN or fibers in the dHC did not reduce locomotor activity or induce place avoidance. • Serotonin neurons in the MRN, and serotonergic input to the dHC, are important for the regulation of anxiety-like behaviour.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The neurotransmitter serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) modulates a wide range of behaviors and physiological functions including feeding, sexual behaviour, reward processing, sleep, aggression, pain and thermoregulation (Cools et al., 2008;Dayan and Huys, 2009;Soubrié, 1986). Dysfunctions of serotonin system activity have also been implicated in a number of psychiatric conditions, particularly https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuropharm.2020.107985 Received 3 September 2019; Received in revised form 29 January 2020; Accepted 31 January 2020 mood disorders and anxiety (Carr and Lucki, 2010;Deakin and Graeff, 1991;Graeff et al., 1996;Guimarães et al., 2010). Notably, serotonergic interventions particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are also the front-line treatment for depression and anxiety (Jones and Blackburn, 2002). Anxiolytic and antidepressant effects of SSRIs appear to involve long-term adaptations in the serotonin system following extended treatment (Bielski et al., 2004). However, short term side effects include exacerbation of negative emotional symptoms and "jitteriness", anxiety, nervousness, restlessness, agitation and irritability (Gorman et al., 1987;Grillon et al., 2007;Ramos et al., 1993). This deleterious acute response to SSRIs may contribute to inefficacy of treatment or cause worsening of psychiatric symptoms. However, relatively little is known about the neural mechanisms underlying the acute anxiogenic effect produced by SSRIs.
Acute SSRI administration enhances extracellular serotonin levels throughout the brain resulting from inhibition of the serotonin transporter (SERT). The majority of serotonin neurons innervating the forebrain originate in the dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) or median raphe nucleus (MRN) (Azmitia and Segal, 1978;Vertes, 1991;Vertes et al., 1999). These two main projection systems differ in a number of ways including innervation patterns, neuronal morphology, presumed mode of neurotransmission, and perhaps behavioural functions (Vertes andLinley, 2008, 2007). Both the DRN and MRN systems have been implicated in the expression of anxiety-like behaviours. Cell-type specific optogenetic manipulation of 5-HT cells in the MRN produce anxiogenic behaviour in male and female mice (Ohmura et al., 2014). Indeed, Fig. 1. (B), Fluorescent microscope image of the MRN displaying the expression of channelrhodopsin-2 conjugated to enhanced yellow fluorescent protein (ChR2-eYFP; green), 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT; red) and both images merged. (C), Schematic representation of a coronal section where the MRN 5-HT neurons are recorded (adapted from Paxinos and Franklin, 2001). (D), Response of an MRN ChR2-eYFP expressing 5-HT neuron in response to depolarizing and hyperpolarizing current injections (25 pA) in a stepwise manner. (E), Typical membrane properties of these neurons (n = 22), including capacitance (Cm), membrane potential (Vm), spike amplitude (spike amp), spike threshold (spike thr), and input resistance (Rinput). (F), Representative voltage-clamp traces from a ChR2-YFP expressing MRN 5-HT neuron in response to bath application of 100 nM 5-CT before and after application of the 5-HT 1A receptor antagonist WAY100635. (G), Typical response to a train of optogenetic stimuli (4 Hz, 10 ms duration pulses, 473 nm) in a ChR2-eYFP expressing 5-HT neuron in the MRN. (H), Quantification of the frequency of action potentials before, after, and in response to a 4 Hz train of optogenetic stimulation for 30 s (n = 16 neurons). **p < 0.01. while pharmacological inactivation of the MRN elicits anxiolytic effects, activation of the MRN is anxiogenic (Andrade et al., 2013). The fact that such effects could be obtained with relatively selective manipulations such as 5-HT-depleting lesions (Andrade and Graeff, 2001), or intracranial infusions of 5-HT selective drugs (Carli et al., 1989;Vicente et al., 2008) supports a specific role for MRN serotonergic neurons in mediating these effects. Andrade et al. (2013) further suggest that serotonergic efferents from the MRN to the dorsal hippocampus (dHC) are especially important for modulating anxiety based on evidence from studies involving simultaneous microinjections of 5-HTacting drugs into both sites (Dos Santos et al., 2008). It was recently demonstrated that selective stimulation of 5-HT terminals in the ventral hippocampus reproduce the anxiogenic effect caused by stimulation of 5-HT cells in the MRN (Ohmura et al., 2019). Despite greater prevalence of anxiety disorders in women (Pigott, 1999), preclinical studies of anxiety-like behaviour in male mice outnumber those using females. Therefore, in the current research we used female mice to investigate the contribution of 5-HT inputs to the dHC to the modulation of anxiety. However, it should be noted that our goal was not to study sex differences in 5-HT modulation of anxiety but to investigate the serotonergic modulation of the dHC while working towards correcting the imbalance in preclinical neuroscience research (Shansky, 2019;Will et al., 2017).
Techniques such as optogenetics provide a way to selectively manipulate neuronal activity in discrete cell populations. Recently, we used this approach to examine the effects of stimulating 5-HT neurons of the DRN on reward-related behaviours (Browne et al., 2019). This involved expressing ChR2 in 5-HT neurons, by crossing mice from the Ai32 conditional ChR2 reporter line with ePet-cre mice that express Cre recombinase driven by the enhancer region of the Pet-1 gene (Scott and Deneris, 2005). As part of this work we showed that stimulation of the DRN activated 5-HT cells leading to enhanced 5-HT release in terminal regions. In the present study we have applied this method to investigate the role of serotonergic efferents from the MRN and serotonergic terminals in the dHC in the expression of anxiety-related behaviours in female mice. We found that stimulation of 5-HT neurons in the MRN increased the expression of anxiety-like behaviours, as measured in several tests of anxiety: exploration on the elevated plus maze, noveltysuppressed feeding and marble-burying. We also confirmed that optogenetic stimulation of the MRN increased 5-HT neuronal activity, and increased release of 5-HT in the dHC. Stimulation of 5-HT terminals in the dHC recapitulated some of these behaviours. These results show that 5-HT output from the MRN rapidly modulates the expression of anxiety-like behaviour, in part via its interaction with the dHC.

sections.heading: Animals
sections.text:
Adult (10+ weeks old) female mice were used in these experiments. Transgenic mice expressing the light-gated cation channel channelrhodopsin-2 (ChR2) were generated as previously described (Browne et al., 2019;Teixeira et al., 2018). Briefly, mice from the serotonergic cre-driver line ePet-cre (Pet1-cre, Jackson 012712, Bar Harbor, Maine, USA) were crossed with mice from the cre-dependent ChR2 reporter line Ai32 (Ai32; Jackson 012569) to direct serotonin-specific expression of ChR2 (Fig. 1A and B). Experimental mice (ChR2+) were homozygous for Ai32 and positive for ePet-cre, while control mice (ChR2-) were homozygous for Ai32 but negative for ePet-cre. Genotyping was carried out according to standard protocols from the Jackson Laboratory.
All mice were housed in temperature and humidity-controlled environments with a 12 h light cycle, with lights on at 7:00 a.m. Mice were group housed, with food and water available ad libitum unless otherwise specified. Experiments adhered to the Canadian Council of Animal Care standards, and followed protocols approved by the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health Animal Care Committee and the University of Toronto Faculty of Medicine Animal Care Committee.

sections.heading: Electrophysiology
sections.text: For electrophysiological experiments, 400 μm brainstem slices including the MRN were obtained using a Dosaka Pro 7 Linear Slicer (DSK) slicer (Fig. 1C). Slicing was performed in ice cold and sucrose substituted artificial cerebrospinal fluid (aCSF) (254 mM sucrose, 10 mM D-glucose, 24 mM NaHCO 3 , 2 mM CaCl 2 , 2 mM MgSO 4 , 3 mM KCl, 1.25 mM NaH 2 PO 4 , pH 7.4) oxygenated with 95% O2/5% CO 2 . Slices were recovered in oxygenated aCSF (128 mM NaCl, 10 mM Dglucose, 26 mM NaHCO 3 , 2 mM CaCl 2 , 2 mM MgSO 4 , 3 mM KCl, 125 mM NaH 2 PO 4 , pH 7.4) at 30 °C for at least 2 h. Recordings were performed in oxygenated aCSF at 30 °C at a rate of 3-4 ml/min 2.5 μM L-tryptophan (Sigma) was added both during recovery and in bath to maintain 5-HT synthesis. Patch pipettes (2-4 MΩ) contained 120 mM Kgluconate, 5 mM KCl, 2 mM MgCl 2 , 4 mM K 2 -ATP, 0.4 mM Na 2 -GTP, 10 mM Na 2 -phosphocreatine, 10 mM HEPES buffer adjusted to pH 7.3 with KOH. Slices were transferred to a perfusion chamber on the stage of an Olympus BX50W1 microscope and MRN 5-HT neurons were visualized based on the expression of EYFP. Whole-cell recordings were obtained in current-clamp or voltage-clamp (at −75 mV) mode using a Multiclamp 700B amplifier (Molecular Devices). 5-CT (100 nM, Tocris) was bath applied to probe 5HT 1A receptor currents which were blocked by application of 5HT 1A receptor antagonist WAY100635 (30 nM, Sigma). Optogenetic stimulation (4 Hz, 10 ms) was performed using blue LED light (473 nM) (Thorlabs). Data were acquired at 20 kHz and low-pass filtered at 3 kHz using pClamp10.2 and Digidata 1440 software. Analysis was performed with pClamp 10.2 software.

sections.heading: Surgical procedure for implanting optical fibers
sections.text: Mice received stereotaxic surgery under isoflurane anesthesia (2%), to implant a single optical fiber in the MRN (from interaural zero: A/P −0.6, M/L 0, D/V +1.75; Paxinos and Franklin, 2001) or bilateral optical fibers in the dorsal hippocampus (from bregma: A/P −1.7, M/ L ± 1.6, D/V −1.0). Optical fiber implants were constructed from a segment of multimode optical fiber (200 μm core, 0.33 NA; Thorlabs, Newton, NJ) threaded through a zirconia ferrule (1.25 mm OD; Thorlabs). Ferrules were fixed to the skull using dental cement (RelyX Unicem; 3M, Maplewood, MN). Animals were given one week of recovery following surgical procedures.

sections.heading: Behavioral procedures
sections.text: Throughout behavioral tests, mice were tethered to optical patch cables (0.37 NA; Doric Lenses, Quebec City, QC, Canada) coupled to an optical commutator (Doric Lenses) which was connected to a 473 nm diode-pumped solid state laser (Laserglow, Toronto, ON, Canada). Laser output was controlled by a waveform generator (Keysight Technologies, Mississauga, ON, Canada).

sections.heading: Novelty-suppressed feeding
sections.text: Prior to testing, mice received 24 h of food restriction which resulted in approximately 10% weight loss. Mice were first allowed to habituate to a novel room for 20 min, after which point mice were placed into the corner of a large transparent arena (55 cm × 28 × 32 cm) and photostimulation directed to the MRN or dHC (4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW) was initiated. Photostimulation remained active until the test was terminated. The arena was filled with 2 cm of bedding (Yesterday's News, Purina) with a single food pellet placed close to one end. Mice were placed in one of the corners farthest from the food pellet and were allowed to explore the arena until a feeding episode began, or for a maximum of 10 min. The latency to approach and investigate the food pellet and the latency to initiate a feeding episode were recorded. Upon completion of the trial, photostimulation was terminated and mice were removed from the arena.

sections.heading: Marble burying
sections.text: Mice were allowed to explore and dig in a large container (24 cm × 32 cm X 30 cm) 20 cm deep with bedding (Yesterday's News, Purina) for 10 min with constant photostimulation applied to the MRN or dHC (4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW). Marbles were placed in the bedding 4 cm apart in eight rows of four. At the end of the 10 min period, the number of marbles covered at least 2/3 by bedding were counted (Deacon, Mice were allowed to habituate to the testing room for 20 min. The elevated-plus maze (EPM) consisted of two gray plastic open arms (30 × 5 cm) perpendicularly conjoined at a center space (5 × 5 cm) with two black plastic enclosed arms attached (30 × 5 × 30 cm). After habituation, mice were placed in the center space of the EPM, and were allowed to explore the maze for 9 min. The test session was divided into 3 min epochs with alternating laser stimulation directed to the MRN or the dHC (OFF-ON-OFF; 4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW). Behavioral parameters including time spent in the open and closed arms were tracked using the Anymaze software (Stoelting, Wood Dale, IL).

sections.heading: Food consumption test
sections.text: Mice were food deprived for 24 h before testing. Mice were allowed to habituate to the room for 20 min. Following habituation, mice were placed into their home cage and photostimulation directed to the MRN or dHC was initiated (4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW). The home cage contained only their bedding (Yesterday's News, Purina) and a single food pellet placed close to one end of the cage. Mice were allowed to explore the cage and consume the food pellet for a maximum of 10 min. The latency to approach and investigate the food pellet, the latency to initiate a feeding episode and the amount of food pellet (in g) consumed recorded.

sections.heading: Real-time place preference
sections.text: After 20 min of habituation to the testing room, mice were placed into an open field arena (36 × 46 cm) and exploration was tracked through an overhead camera connected to Anymaze software. The arena was divided into four quadrants (14 × 19 cm). Entry into one of two diagonally opposing quadrants initiated photostimulation directed to the MRN or the dHC (4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW) via Anymazegenerated TTL pulses that triggered laser activation until the animal exited the quadrant. Entry into the other two quadrants of the arena had no consequence. Time spent in each quadrant was recorded.

sections.heading: Locomotor behaviour test
sections.text:
After a 20-min habituation to the testing room, mice were placed in open field arena (70 cm × 70 cm X 30 cm) for 9 min. The test session was divided into 3 min epochs with alternating photostimulation directed to the MRN or the dHC (OFF-ON-OFF; 4 Hz, 10 ms pulse width, 10 mW). Behavioral parameters including distance travelled tracked through an overhead camera using Anymaze. Under control conditions mice spent very little time in the central area of the test arena (likely because of arena size and lighting conditions).

sections.heading: In vivo microdialysis
Histology and Immunohistochemistry
sections.text:
Following all behavioural and neurochemical procedures, mice were sacrificed and their brains were processed for histology. Mice in behavioural experiments were sacrificed via transcardial perfusion with 4% paraformaldehyde. Mice used in microdialysis experiments were sacrificed by cervical dislocation. In both cases, brains were extracted, in 4% paraformaldehyde, and subsequently cryoprotected in 30% sucrose before being sectioned into 40 μm thick sections on a cryostat. For amplification of EYFP-ChR2 and quantification of colocalization with 5-HT neurons, sections were immunostained according to standard procedures (primary antibodies: rabbit anti-GFP 1:1000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA), and goat anti-5-HT (Abcam, Cambridge, UK) 1:1000; secondary antibodies: donkey anti-rabbit A488 (Thermo) 1:1000 and donkey anti-goat A555 (Thermo) 1:1000.
were imaged using an Olympus FV3000 confocal microscope. of colocalization was performed using Image J, with analysis restricted to the MRN. EYFP labeled cells were identified and subsequently determined to be positive or negative for 5-HT. A total of 583 EYFP+ cells were identified across three sections per animal (n=4, average per animal: 145 cells).

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: behavioural statistical analyses were conducted using SPSS v.18 (N.Y., U.S.A.) and electrophysiological analyses were conducted with Prism 7 (GraphPad). In most cases, behavioural data was analyzed using an independent samples t-test with mice grouped by the presence or absence of ChR2 expression (novelty-suppressed feeding, food consumption test, marble burying, real-time place preference, microdialysis). For tests that involved temporal manipulations of optogenetic stimulation (elevated-plus maze, open-field test), a two-way mixed ANOVA was applied (within-subjects factor: time bin, 3 levels; between-subjects factor: genotype, 2 levels). Planned comparisons were also conducted in each time bin, established a priori based on the experimental to compare mice expressing ChR2 during the period of photostimulation. The dependent measure for the open-field test was distance travelled. The dependent measure for dialysis was the concentration of 5-HT measured in the dorsal hippocampus. Homogeneity of variance was assessed with Mauchly's sphericity test. If a violation of this assumption was detected, the F-term was assessed using degrees of with a Greenhouse-Geisser correction. Fisher's least significant difference was used for all post-hoc tests and planned comparisons.

sections.heading: Optogenetic stimulation activates MRN 5-HT neurons
sections.text: ChR2+ mice (Fig. 1A) displayed a high degree of selectivity for ChR2-EYFP expression in MRN 5-HT neurons (Fig. 1B), with 87.6% ( ± 2.9%) of ChR2-EYFP-positive cells also positive for 5-HT. Electrophysiological recordings were performed on MRN slices obtained from ChR2+ mice (Fig. 1A). MRN neurons were identified based on the expression of EYFP and on electrophysiological characteristics (Fig. 1B-D ; et al., 2004). Following optogenetic stimulation, MRN neurons responded to bath application of the 5-HT receptor agonist 5-CT (100 nM) with an outward inhibitory current (Fig. 1F) that is blocked by the application of 5-HT 1A receptor antagonist WAY100635 (30 nM). Optogenetic stimulation (473 nm, 10 ms pulses) of MRN neurons produced a robust firing response at a frequency corresponding to the frequency of photostimulation at 4 Hz (Fig. 1G-H).

sections.heading: Activation of MRN 5-HT neurons promotes anxiety-like behaviour
sections.text: Novelty-suppressed feeding During a 10 min period of photostimulation directed to the MRN, ChR2+ mice took significantly longer to approach food (Fig. 2A; t 15 = 2.563, p < 0.05) and to begin consuming food (Fig. 2B; t 15 = 1.787, p < 0.05) in a novel environment.

sections.heading: Marble burying
sections.text: During a 10 min period of photostimulation directed to the MRN, ChR2+ mice displayed significantly more marble burying than control mice (Fig. 2C; t 15 = 3.317, p < 0.01).

sections.heading: Elevated-plus maze
sections.text: One ChR2+ mouse was excluded from the analysis due to disruptions during testing. All mice spent less time in the open arms as the progressed (Fig. 2D; F (2,28) = 18.099, p < 0.001). No difference in open arm time was observed between ChR2+ and ChR2-mice across the entire session (F (1,14) = 1.550, p > 0.05). However, planned comparisons across photostimulation epochs found that although ChR2+ and ChR2-mice were similar during the "OFF" epochs (without photostimulation; Fig. 2D; all p > 0.05, ns), a significant reduction in open arm time was observed for ChR2+ during the "ON" epoch when photostimulation was applied (Fig. 2E; p < 0.05).

sections.heading: Food consumption test
sections.text: During a 10 min period of photostimulation directed to the MRN, ChR2+ mice did not differ from ChR2-mice in the latency to approach food (Fig. 2F; t 15 = 0.133, p > 0.05) or to begin consuming food (Fig. 2G; t 15 = 0.414, p > 0.05) in a familiar environment.

sections.heading: Real-time place preference
sections.text: ChR2+ and ChR2-mice did not differ in the amount of time spent in the zones (see 2H) associated with photostimulation directed to the MRN (Fig. 2I; t 15 = 0.3715, p > 0.05).

sections.heading: Locomotor behavior test
sections.text: All mice showed within-session reductions in activity (Fig. 2J; F (2,30) = 63.027, p < 0.001). Across the entire session, ChR2+ mice did not differ from ChR2-mice in distance travelled (F (1,15) = 0.348, p > 0.05), nor was there a significant ChR2 x Time interaction (F (2,30) = 1.629, p > 0.05).

sections.heading: In vivo microdialysis of 5-HT in the dorsal hippocampus (dHC)
sections.text: Photostimulation of the MRN for 10 min produced an increase in 5- HT concentration in the dHC of mice expressing ChR2 (Fig. 3A) although the magnitude of this increase was variable. ChR2+ mice exhibited a significantly greater increase in 5-HT concentration during the stimulation period relative to baseline compared to ChR2-mice 3B; p < 0.05).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
The present work characterizes the role of 5-HT neurons originating in the MRN and their interaction with the dHC in regulating anxietylike behaviour. Using an optogenetic approach, we show that stimulating MRN 5-HT neurons causes an anxiogenic response in mice using three tests of anxiety: the novelty-suppressed feeding test, marble burying, and elevated-plus maze. Furthermore, we show that some of these behavioral responses are also observed following selective stiof 5-HT terminals in the dHC. However, photostimulation of either the MRN or 5-HT input to the dHC did not cause a real-time place aversion, suggesting that the effects observed in the tests of anxiety are not due to an inherently aversive property of optogenetic stimulation. These observations support a specific role for 5-HT neurons originating in the MRN-and their projection to the dHC-in the expression of anxiety-like behaviour.
The present finding that MRN stimulation is anxiogenic under various test conditions is consistent with previous work using a variety of surgical, pharmacological and genetic approaches (for review, see Andrade et al., 2013). Lesions of the MRN in rats tend to reduce the expression of anxiety-like behaviour; these effects have been observed with both electrolytic (Andrade and Graeff, 2001;et al., 1998) and serotonin-selective neurotoxic lesions (Silva et al., 2002(Silva et al., , 2004and Graeff, 2001). It should be noted, however, that in some cases selective lesions of 5-HT neurons in the MRN had no effect on anxiety-like behaviour in the elevated-plus maze (Netto et al., 2002;et al., 2000) or in a test of social interaction (File et al., 1979), which may be due to compensation in other circuits that receive 5-HT input such as the periaqueductal gray or the amygdala, which also support the expression of anxiety. Consistent with the anxiogenic effects of MRN lesions, temporary inactivation of the MRN using 5-HT 1A agonists increases avoidance of several naturally aversive test stimuli, including the open arms in the elevated-plus maze , conspecifics in tests of social interaction (Andrews et al., 1994), and the illuminated chamber in the light/dark test (Carli and Samanin, 1988). Activation of MRN neurons, using electrical stimulation or specific pharmacological activation of 5-HT neurons, promote anxietylike behaviour (Graeff and Silveira Filho, 1978;. These effects are comparable to those reported here using an optogenetic approach chosen for its selectivity for 5-HT neurons. Many of effects involving manipulation of neuronal activity of the MRN have also been shown to be similar between male and female subjects (Andrade et al., 2009(Andrade et al., , 2005De Almeida and Lucion, 1997). Further, our findings replicate a recent demonstration that optogenetic manipulation of 5-HT output from the MRN enhances anxiety-like behaviour in the elevated-plus maze in both male and female mice (Ohmura et al., 2019(Ohmura et al., , 2014. We extend these latter findings to show that this anxiogenic-like effect occurs in other test situations including marble-burying and feeding in a novel environment. The results of a number of control tests rule out the possibility that these effects are mediated by generalized disruptions in locomotor activity, feeding behaviour or stimulation-induced aversion. Collectively, all of this work demonstrates an important role for MRN 5-HT neurons in the modulation of anxietylike behaviour.
The MRN and DRN both provide strong serotonergic innervation of the forebrain, including to a number of limbic structures implicated in the regulation of anxiety such as the hippocampus, and septum (Vertes, 1991;. Despite these similarities, the MRN and DRN give rise to overlapping yet distinct neural circuits that differ in terms of their projection patterns, neuronal morphology, neurotransmission dynamics, and potentially the behavioral functions supported by each (for review, see Calizo et al., 2011). For example, while the dorsal periaqueductal gray area receives innervation primarily from the DRN, the dHC receives mostly 5-HT input from the MRN (Vertes, 1991;Vertes et al., 1999). Given these differences, the MRN and DRN may interact with these structures in a circuit-specific manner to modulate anxiety, though the mechanics underlying this circuitry have not been thoroughly characterized. In one study, Dos  demonstrated that microinjection of a 5-HT antagonist into the MRN, to increase 5-HT activity, facilitated acquisition of inhibitory avoidance, -an effect that was blocked by pre-administration of the same 5-HT antagonist in the dHC (Dos . Based on this finding, it has been postulated that 5-HT input to the dHC arising from the MRN plays an important role in the regulation of anxiety (Andrade et al., 2013), though until now this hypothesis has not been directly addressed. Using an optogenetic approach that is anatomically and cellspecific, we show that activation of 5-HT terminals in the dHC induced anxiogenic behavioural responses. This effect closely mirrored the effect of MRN stimulation, indicating that the projection of 5-HT neurons from the MRN to the dHC is important for regulating the expression of anxiety-like behaviour.
Stimulation of the dHC produced an anxiogenic response in the novelty-suppressed feeding and marble burying tests, but not in the elevated-plus maze. The expression of anxiety is a complex behavioural process, supported by an elaborate set of circuits throughout the brain. In addition the interaction we have shown here between the MRN and the dHC, the MRN projects to several other brain regions that contribute to the regulation of anxiety (Vertes et al., 1999), including the amygdala complex (Tye et al., 2011). Furthermore, although the MRN is the predominant source of 5-HT input in the dHC (Vertes et al., 1999), the dHC also receives some 5-HT input from the DRN. Given that pharmacological manipulations of 5-HT function in the DRN alter anbehaviour (File et al., 1979;; but see Ohmura et al., 2014), the interaction of the DRN with the dHC may also contribute to the regulation of anxiety-like behaviour. Future studies should delineate the specific contribution of 5-HT terminals in structures other than the dHC, in the regulation of anxiety.
The results of the current study demonstrate the importance of 5-HT input to the dHC in the regulation of anxiety. Based on these results, the functional interaction occurring between 5-HT input to the dHC seems to involve the control of behaviour in contexts that involve a conflict between approach and avoidance. This was observed in a variety of behavioural paradigms, including novelty-suppressed feeding and marble burying. For many years, the interaction between 5-HT system and the hippocampus has been characterized as part of a broader behavioural inhibition system (Gray, 1982). Under this system, anxiety is presumed to be a result of inhibition of ongoing behaviour in response to detection of innately fear-provoking stimuli (e.g., open spaces). Further, the hippocampus may act as a comparator between expected and actual environmental stimuli (Gray, 1987), which would activate the behavioural inhibition system the two are mismatched (e.g. in the presence of an approach-avoidance conflict). The results of the current study provide strong evidence for the role of 5-HT input to the hippocampus as part of the behavioural inhibition system, especially as pertains to the control of ongoing behaviour in innately contexts. In conclusion, these studies show that 5-HT neurons originating in the MRN, and their interaction with the dHC, contribute to the expression anxiety. This interaction represents one possible mediator of the effects produced by short-term SSRI treatment. Future work should examine the effect of chronic upregulation of activity in this circuit to determine if context associations formed during testing, and their associated expressions of anxiety, are potentiated across time. Furthermore, the specific receptor mechanisms underlying the interaction between 5-HT terminals and the dHC is unknown. Future studies should delineate the specific contribution of 5-HT receptor subtypes in the dHC, such as 5-HT 1A , underlying the regulation of anxiety. Closer examination of the receptor mechanisms underlying the interactions between the serotonergic system interacts and other circuits will shed light on the etiology of anxiety and help refine treatment strategies.

figures.figure_caption: Fig. 2 .2Fig.2. Photostimulation of 5-HT neurons in the median raphe nucleus (MRN) produces anxiety-like behavior in a variety of behavioral tests. Optogenetic stimulation of 5-HT neurons in the MRN for 10 min increases the time taken by mice to approach (A) and begin consuming (B) food in the novelty-suppressed feeding test and (C) increases the number of covered marbles in the marble burying test. In the elevated plus-maze test, optogenetic stimulation of MRN neurons during the middle time bin (3 min, D-E) increases the amount of time spent in the open arms. Optogenetic stimulation of these neurons had no effect on the time taken by mice to approach (F) and begin consuming (G) food in the food consumption test, (H,I) the time spent in the zones associated with stimulation, or (J) locomotor activity. *p < 0.05.
